evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as documented in the hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident remains robust against alternative interpretations within the hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident within the hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as documented in the hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: Lack of warning signals and limited visual contact imply communication/coordination breakdown among crew.
The trainee and instructor roles and their interactions reflect crew coordination.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and timely warnings from wingman or headset operator preventing the incident.
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 directly describe communication and coordination among crew and ground personnel, highlighting lack of warning signals and limited visual contact, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether communication failure or procedural deviation was primary cause; limited explicit statements on crew coordination breakdown.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident within the hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown is indicated by lack of warning signals and failure to stop pushback timely.
The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator constitutes a coordination failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if the incident was primarily due to procedural deviation rather than communication failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H2 show communication among crew during pushback, and H8 indicates a failure in communication/coordination as no warning was given before collision, supporting the claim of communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication failure or procedural deviation was primary cause

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident remains robust against alternative interpretations within the hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.

defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or timely warnings from wingman or headset operator that prevented the collision, or if procedural deviations better explained the event, the robustness claim would be weakened.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, and H9 directly describe communication and coordination dynamics among crew and tug operators, supporting the robustness of the communication breakdown explanation. Discriminators show this explanation is favored over procedural deviation and marking deficiency alternatives.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity remains about the exact timing and effectiveness of communication signals and whether alternative explanations might fit unreported details.
